But wow, the burgers were GREAT. I think I had the basic, no frills burger (can't quite remember) and it has got to be the best burger I've tasted in a while. I had it a few weeks ago and I can still remember it. The service could have been a little better; our waitress seemed aloof.

This is and will always be one of my favorite bars but the manager working tonight in 6/11/2015 was really nasty to me just now. I came with two friends and we sat at the bar and had a few beers and at two orders of dumpling and we left $95 dollars on a $71 dollar bill.  He chased me and my boss outside and said our bill was "light" so we told him what we left and he said "no one steals at his bar" nice try dude it's NYC.  It was my fault for not handing it directly to the waitress.  But someone definitely stole from his bar.  Anyway I still like this bar but if you see a short blonde British manager make sure to tell him he's an ass and give your bill directly to the waitress.  Keep in mind we paid the bill again because we didn't want to argue or have the waitress deal with the issue.  But congratulations new manager guy I've been bringing my friends and clients here for years and you have ruined my night.  Ear inn is a good bar.  That guy sucks.

Barry is the greatest bartender/person who has ever lived. The EAR INN is one of the best/most historically awesome bars in NYC! Went there for the first time on Tuesday night with my boy toy and my bestie and had a WONDERFUL experience. I also really appreciate that they don't have a deep fryer. I ate some delicious spicy shrimp and an amazing turkey burger (which may or may not have been a hamburger, but who's counting). A cool, happy place worth checking out. The kind of place you want to be a regular at! 5 stars!!

When we visited NY our actor daughter took us to this bar/restaurant. It is a small place but with a very friendly atmosphere. We were there on a Sunday night and the highlight of the evening was the very good Jazz group that performed, The Eargulars. The food was good tasting and reasonably priced for NYC. The service was very good, friendly and accommodating. This is a popular spot with artists. We got there at 7 PM and left at 2 AM. It maybe a different experience during the day.

This is like a old bar out in the back ends of Ireland somewhere. I'm off the boat Irish, and I love it! My boyfriend brought me here. The atmosphere was very friendly, and laid back. Bar tender was attentive. There is outdoor seating, but no tables, and seating is limited. There were people sitting and standing outside, drinking and hanging out. I didn't have any food, but I would like to try it, it smelled really good!

This awesome institution is a hidden gem! The bartenders are charming, the ambiance is cosy and the menu is full of my favorite comfort food. It's a great place for a chill date or a meal with friends. I especially love he old phone booth. Score!

Came here on a recommendation by a friend..didn't have any expectations really but was pleasantly surprised. Staff is very friendly, food is very reasonably priced (7$ for about 20 Mussels in a great white wine sauce) and they have a pretty good original brew as well. Very old, but very cool considering the history behind the place. Would recommend it to anyone in the area to try at least once, as it is the 2nd oldest bar in NYC.

I stumbled  in here with a group of four after a birthday party at a bar/club in the neighborhood.  This offered the perfect dive bar / laid back atmosphere we were seeking after being at a louder more intense bar for most of the night.   The bartenders were very nice and friendly. I'm usually not this far southwest in NYC, but would love to find a reason to have another Boddingtons or two at The Ear.

I only come here for lunch with my boss/colleagues, so I don't know what it's like after work hours. BUT that being said, if you're in the area it's worth a visit. It's super old, creaky, and when you enter, it feels like you've been completely removed from NYC and placed into an old secret speakeasy. Strangely, if you read the story of this very special house on the back of the menu (and it has quite an interesting history), you'll find that at some point in time it was a speakeasy. Eccentric & very cool knick-knacks, random pictures, and ornaments scatter all over the walls and it does have a homey feel.The food is generally consistently good, and the prices are reasonable. Mostly bar-type food, but they have specials every day, though they seem to largely remain the same every time I've visited. My co-workers love their burger, but I particularly like their side roasted potatoes. The wait staff is superrr friendly and occasionally you'll get an waitress with an Irish accent. :)OH and when your right outside the front door, check out the line marking the Hudson River shore from back in the 1800s. Pretty amazing stuff.

I can see why this is my doppelganger's favorite bar! It's charming through and through, from the friendly, laid-back, bar staff with their cute accents, to the patrons with their dogs and motorcycles who seem to co-exist peacefully while drinking Hooegaardens and Boddingtons on the sidewalk out front. Not an ounce of pretension detected here!It's also a great place to view a New York sunset.

I kind of love this place. It's a shame I've only been here once. A friend who lives in the SoHo area suggested it. I work right around the corner and have never seen it. Upon first sight it's pretty quaint. The sign is made out of an old neon 'BAR' sign with the corners of the B blacked out to look like 'EAR' which got a good laugh from my boyfriend and I.It's very small, but we sat near the back which was nice. I can imagine sitting towards the front could get a little annoying. The inside is old and cunning. Very European! Reminds me of the bars we used to head out too when I was living in Wales, which is where my boyfriend is from, so he was right at home here. The beer was good, not a huge selection like I'm used too, but good! Their house special is fantastic and their food was pretty good. Typical pub food, I had the irish beef stew myself as it was a special. I loved it! Very filling. Not to expensive for my boyfriend, myself and our three friends I certainly wasn't regretting treating! The wait staff was fantastic. Plus I got to doodle on the table, which is awesome in it's own right.The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because it gets really, and I mean really, loud. Pubs are usually loud but there's so many people so close together that you can't really have a conversation, even a pub one. Plus the lady in the next table over was listening in on our conversation because of this fact and kept butting in. It's not really the pubs fault, but it is rather annoying. Also the bathrooms are so small it was a little awkward.

I like this place.  It's a dark, small, cozy, self-confident bar - not at all concerned about how it looks, and always ready for a good time.  A real friendly neighborhood place, with a good cheery clientele.I came in here with a friend just before five on a Friday night, and this place was jam packed with.....white hairs.  We assumed - all the guys that don't work anymore during a regular day - they come on a weekday afternoon to get down at Ear Inn!  So we felt a little out of place at first, as two 24 year old women, but we knew Ear had good reviews, so we stuck it out and waited for the rest of our crew.They came around 5:30.  We secured a big table in the back.  By 6 the room had changed completely, and transformed into the all-ages working people of NYC.  Packed!  The menu is simple, but everything on it was great.  My friends and I ordered the salmon dish (it comes on a bed of greens) and it was delicious - juicy, perfectly cooked, fresh greens.  Huge plate, too.  So we were satisfied with that.  Everyone else seemed generally pleased with their meals as well.  The place gets happily loud too, which works for us.  Spacewise, you might not be able to get anywhere near the bar, but there is table service, and we were able to get a constant wine supply before we even ordered food, which was pro.Definitely a good neighborhood place you'll want to hit up if you want to do something really casual on a budget.  VERY reasonable prices (for drinks as well) and enough space in the back room for a good sized group.  This would be the ideal place for an I-just-got-outta-work-in-Soho dinner and a couple casual drinks before moving on to more happening hoods.

cute little bar! good drinks... the "Michalada" was new to me, and really tasty! I'm from SoCal and have never heard of it (wierd).  Also, the women's restroom felt like the smallest bathroom in the world. :)

I love drinking beers outside at Ear Inn. It's like drinking on the street- but legal. I wonder how much longer it will last with the area changing so much every year. Food is pretty decent too. See ya in the Spring  for more outdoor boozing (I hope).
not a good spot for hanging out at the bar if you are with a group of 5 or more. too crowded!

i concur with alot of Yelpers - great food and warm atmosphere.  The owner, Martin knows how to run a real pub.  The bartenders and waitresses are solid and never tire of serving food and drink.  If you are ready to relax and put in a 'session' of imbibing and nibbling - this in the place!  Slainte!

Gotta love the ambiance... the bartender the night I was there was a character hahaha the crayons on the table made the night become an art show hahaha awesome spot to chill and laugh with your friends...

Excellent, cheap burger.  $8.50 plus $1 for cheese... a steal given the old New York ambiance. I sat in the back and there were plenty of seats at 8p on a Wednesday. A cool place to grab a drink and sit outside too. Wait staff were a bit inattentive when I was ready for the check, but quickly got it over when I asked for it.
The Irish bartender is a complete prick, but the food is decent.

The Ear Inn is a great place for an informal meal and a drink, kind of a neighborhood bar & grill.  Food is very good, and prices are quite reasonable for NYC.  The place is small and crowded, but in a friendly way (i.e. you don't feel squashed).  I've only been here twice, but both times the food and service were quite good.  Note that the dinner menu and specials is not available until 6pm, prior to that you can order from the lunch menu (burgers, appetizers, etc).
Came here for a lunch meeting. We both had the lamb burger, and weren't disappointed. It's definitely a good place for lunch and I'm told that you can always get a table.

Pretty cool ambiance. Crayons on the table turned me into an artist. I ordered the Salmon over mixed greens aka Salmon Salad with no dressing. I needed something on that. I should have asked for ranch dressing.Maybe it was because I saw the burger and got jealous, but I was just not feeling the Salmon. It was a bit dry for me. If i were to relive the experience, I would have picked the Burger. Next time, if there is one.

All but the last 5 minutes was good about this dining experience. It's an old pub, reminiscent of one you'd find in England or Ireland, and they serve decent food that's reasonably priced.The only gripe I had, was that towards the end of the meal we could smell something really horrible. It made us all feel pretty nauseous, and after a minute or so wondering what it was, we decided it must be a gas leak.I approached the barman and told him. Concerned, he began to investigate, but then stopped after realising what it was: the smell of the dumplings.Apparently the dumplings tend to smell like that - something in the way they're cooked. If you're going to dine in this place, don't eat them! Or sit within 10 yards of someone else who's eating them! If you do order them you'll lose your appetite, and probably the friends you're dining with.

I really like the Ear Inn. Have been coming here regularly recently after work & they always manage to fit big groups of us in with no problem. Drinks are standard and the service is good.My coworkers are obsessed with the chili.Also, there are crayons on the tables for drawing while you sit!!

Just got home from my last trip to what used to be my favorite restaurant.Indignation, an upset stomach and soaked trousers is not something I deserve to experience by choosing to patronize a restaurant.As I already mentioned, this used to be my favorite place to go for a burger or maybe a fish entree, or both! I'd take groups of friends, dates, everyone. I first went there when a good friend of mine was playing jazz on one of their live music nights and just loved it.That said, today's experience has destroyed any desire of mine to ever return.So here's the story, I walk in a little after 7 with a friend, greet the bartender and waitress and are shown to the corner table in the back. I sit down and realize I just sat in a rather large amount of mystery liquid that was pooled in the contours of my seat. I get up and go tell the waitress that there's liquid on my seat and that I sat in it, and go to the restroom to try and soak as much as possible out of my trousers. I'm not going to say that it was urine, but it sure did look and smell like it. After I've soaked up as much as possible I head back out and ask the waitress if it's been cleaned up, which she says it has been. I go look and there's still a few spots of wetness, so I go and ask for a couple napkins. She then repeats herself saying that she cleaned it up, to which I say there is still some there.Did I mention that they didn't apologize to me once for this? I'm not one to make mountains out of molehills, I've worked as a server before so cut a lot of slack when it comes to mishaps, but not apologizing for something like this is not acceptable.So now, with dry seat and apparently a new waitress, we sit trying to act like nothing happened as to not ruin our dining experience, we order our burgers, both with swiss cheese and sauteed mushrooms, my friend's cooked medium and mine medium-well.The burgers come out with with sauteed onions, I point it out but say it's fine but the waitress quickly went and threw some mushrooms on top(apparently they are pre-cooked and kept next to the grill. I remember jokingly saying "strike two" at that point. My friend took a bite and showed me his very rare burger, mine was fine. Sipping my soda and eating the trusty Ear Inn burger, all seemed fine.We get the bill and I can't say I that I wasn't disappointed to see that our two sodas were on it. You ruin a customer's pants, you comp at LEAST a drink, restaurant 101. They have also raised their prices by about 30% since the last time I've been there. Were glasses of soda always $2.50? I honestly didn't feel bad leaving only 2 or 3 dollars as a tip.On the way out I ask the older bartender if he happened to be a manager, wanting to explain briefly what happened. Without any words, he walks away from me and gets a matchbook with the place's phone number on it and hands it to me. Not one word.Do you want to be treated like this? Then don't come here because there is a chance you will be.I had to head home to change my mystery liquid laden trousers and underwear, at which point I realize I've gotten a bad stomach ache- and all that comes with that...I will be calling soon to see if the owner/manager has anything to say about this atrocious series of events.To be clear on my rating, I would have given it two stars if I had not gotten the upset stomach. I would have given it three stars with adequate service and no rumbling bowels. I would have given it four stars with great service and no diarrhea. Lastly I would have given it 5 stars if I was engulfed in a time warp sitting here writing this, and I had just left having been served by the nice waitresses of years past, fair to low prices of a year ago and the nice feeling of having had a nice meal at my favorite restaurant.We had a good run old friend, but you can't treat me like that.

Came here with my buddy Liam several years ago after attending the showing of Brotherhood at the Tribeca Film Festival.  We posted up at the end of the bar and camped out for a couple of hours and had an amazing time.I forgot about this place and stumbled across it the other night.  It is another perfect NYC bar, and one of the oldest dating back to 1817...just my style!Service was quick and we were well attended to the entire time we were there.  Very cozy feel.  Cool matchbooks with two blank music bars in case you feel like composing.  Also has a huge ship mooring hook outside...makes for a cool place to set your drink!

You know when you do not want to go far, you're in a tracksuit and you just want to eat and chat with 2 friends and maybe hear some jazzy sounds? well the ear inn is your place!ohh ohh ohh I could never belong to you (repeat 2 times)

ear inn is a-ok.  the main draw here is the atmosphere for me.  there's an awful lot of wood and old photos tacked up on the walls.  also, a good number of signs warning you not to use your cell phone.  i haven't eaten much of the food, but the beers are solid.  the ear inn ale is surprisingly good, though at $6.50 not exactly a bargain.  another bonus is the paper tablecloths and crayons at every table. this is especially helpful when you and your friends need to work out the logistics of your next heist and forgot the blueprints at home.

2nd oldest bar in NYC, that's a cool pedigree to boast about.  After hitting up Smith and Mills a few blocks away we walked down here, an easy 5-10 min walk, for some more libations.  There were more people here than at S&M, the energy seemed higher, most likely due to the fact the Yankees were playing to stay in the playoffs but they ended up losing this night.  Drink selection here was bigger, the locals friendly and we ended up being sociable and chatting with people around us, which we never do being the antisocial gits that we are.

Stories.  Life is full of 'em.  Good or bad, they are our memories.Me?  I love a good story, and I love the places I visit to have a good story.  This bar, allegedly the second-oldest in NYC, is full of stories, old and new.   You can feel it in the decor, in the knowing eyes of the bartender...everywhere in this bar.Case in point, exemplified by something that happened on our way TO the Ear Inn:Man on the street: "Do you know what the best nation in the world is, starts with a 'D'?"Me: Uuuhhh, Denmark??MOTS: "DO-nation."(Oh, this is but a taste of this persistent young man who followed us for close to 10 blocks trying to get a sale.)My story that night involved a lovely dinner followed by a few random stops for after-dinner cocktails culminated by a very long walk to this bar (upon the insistence and subsequent direction of the sweetest man in the world).  We were able to grab a few seats at the bar, enjoy a pint, and take it all in.  Later, on our long walk back home, I got a street rose that came all the way back to Chicago with me.  Yes, that flower man was persistent, and he was right, "Generosity" is the best city.Like the Ear, I now have my own story that makes me think of the night we ended up at the second oldest bar in New York.  Love it.

This spot is amazing. The location is slightly off the main artery of foot traffic, but that makes it all the better.First, the food: holy f---. It was good. Not mind blowing rethink what you know about the culinary arts good, but questioning the tearing capacity of your stomach good. I had the pork chops and apple sauce, which was standard and well made, but my girlfriend had the crab cakes and mussels and they were both fantastic. Amazingly fantastic. I'm not a seafood fan and I was blown away by how good the crab cakes were.The whole restaurant has a great old New York aesthetic and the building is a great historic landmark. The service is friendly and a bit more down home charm than most places in Manhattan.I highly recommend the Ear Inn to anyone that wants a great meal at a good price served with a charm not often encountered in the big city.

The Ear Inn isn't a typical place I would go to for lunch, but it was convenient for today when I met my 2 friends and the place was in the middle of both of our offices.  It was quite affordable for a sit-down lunch.  It's an old looking place (classic I guess you can call it), tucked away down Spring Street towards the Hudson River.  We all had tuna melts (different toppings - tomato, cucumber, plain) and the waitress got it all right :).  A definite plus.  The bill came out to $32!  Not too shabby!  I will probably be back.  Oh, and we got there right when they opened at noon and when we left at 1pm, not a table empty!!!!

Many a night I have ended up here after Sway. Guess what? It's the latest I've ever stayed out in NYC... Funky stuff on the walls makes for great fun after a round of dancing and a few vodka sodas across the street. The complete opposite of Sway, and, accordingly, a great and mellow counterpart.

It could definitely pass as the 2nd oldest bar in NYC. The paintings look like they could fall off the wall at any minute, the doors have long since left their frames and I'm pretty sure the ceiling is starting to cave in at the back of the bar.Came here for a Birthday party...which be forewarned: If you plan to bring more than a table load of people, plan to go somewhere else. We were actually kicked out because we were taking up too much space. And you can't really just stand around. So even though we would have continued to spend a boat load of money...I guess they didn't want our business. But then again, being the 2nd oldest bar in the city...maybe they've proven they don't need our mula.Before we got the boot, the drinks were plentiful, the wine was surprising alright for a bar of that caliber and the waitress was friendly and talked in some Europe accent. They all sound the same, no? I'm not sure what the "no cell phone" policy is all about, because it was pretty damn loud in there to start.The accept cc's but can only split a table with two. And although I didn't try the food, it all looked to be a very hearty, home-cooked, comfort menu: quiche, Shepard's and chicken pot pie, chili...and then filet mignon? Not sure how that fits in...or really if it'd be any good.I'll definitely go back.
Not worth visiting. Extremely incompetent staff; poor service, incredibly rude. Disgusting trashy regulars. Go elsewhere: old news, with the emphasis on old.
Wondering how the Ear Inn fared during Hurrican Sandy? Are you okay?

Every time I've been at the Ear Inn, it's been a pleasant and totally different experience - an odd cocktail of nautical kitsch, dive-bar familiarity, and Old New York. I was introduced through a co-worker, who suggested dinner and drinks there on a cold, windy, and quite miserable November weekday. A hearty chowder and a beer served in the old galley-looking main room made me feel more like Sir Francis Drake than a famished Manhattanite. The next time I returned, it was after-hours and a friendly Irish lass was more than accommodating, pouring out drinks and giving my friend and I shots of  Jameson, because we clearly needed it. And it's off the beaten path, which is ship-shape by me.

I'm glad I can now say that I've been to the 2nd oldest bar in New York City.  We stopped in for a quick beer and had whatever the house beer was.  Not too big of a place but great for a couple of people to hangout.  Not a pick up spot or somewhere you can dance but I don't think that was the goal of this bar.

IF you want a oldschool place with a local vibe this place rocks. We came in at around 1:30am We asked if they were still serving food the bartender said that they were. We ordered a bunch of the yummiest burgers you will find. the burgers came with salad, and some wicked good potatoes. The waitress even though a little sauced up and wanting to go home was super nice, and fun to deal with. the crowd was cool and it was a great vibe.

We heard that this was one of the oldest bars in NYC and we were staying in SoHo so we checked it out and boy, were we glad we did. The Ear lives up to its' reputation and previous reviews. It's a great neighborhood pub, cozy, with a local crowd and an engaging, friendly bartender from Dublin. It's the kind of place I could go in as a woman alone and feel comfortable and chat with the patrons at the bar. Not many places make you feel as welcome and comfortable these days.

As so many Yelpers have noted, Ear Inn has charm coming out its...er...ears.  It is so much more than a bar -- it's like a sea captain's parlor (read: living room) on the night of a party.  Well-worn and cozy, the space basically renders the need for a menu moot.  They offer shepherds pie, meatloaf, lamb stew, and such, as well as the "spicy" shrimp I tried, which came with a savory-licious generous broth and about twenty cloves of minced garlic.  Plenty of good beer, more tables than bar, and within sight of a pier, this is a comfortable place for a pint, a snack, or a meal.

Fantastic place.A friend and I were headed to a birthday party at Anchor Bar, but when we got there we weren't quite ready for the darkness, loud music, and crazy dancing that is the Anchor Bar experience. My friend said she'd heard of an historic beer bar just down the street, so we decided to stop into the Ear Inn for a couple of drinks before going back to Anchor Bar.Ear Inn was FANTASTIC. It's incredibly old and has a small, quaint atmosphere. It's crowded with lots of small tables and wooden chairs and the bar had more than several aged regulars that looked permanently parked at their stools. The two people behind the bar had authentic Irish accents and were incredibly friendly. The service was so-so, but the drinks were good and the crowd was fun.Not great for large crowds and there's obviously no dancing, but perfect if you and a couple of friends are looking for a casual place with an old-school neighborhood dive bar feel to it.
Friendly local watering hole. Would recommend you seek it out and soak up some history and booze.
I've updated my rating to give props to the inn for it's historical value and hospitable staff.  My original review was unnecessarily harsh.

Meh, It's okay for a chilled night if you have a great group of friends with you, don't expect to come here to find a fascinating crowd. The food is quite good, and very well priced. The atmosphere is cosy and noisy. It's a cute place, but, as I said, don't expect it to be a crazy night.

Get there before the Tribeca crowd gets too thick and enjoy one of the true old school bars left in the city. Won't be surprised to hear sooner rather than later that it's going belly-up in favor of some douchey lounge. Not many places left that play classic country music all night. Good comfort food and you can draw on the paper table cloths with crayons.

Been there a couple of times now - has decent live music but the place was completely empty. Maybe 1:30 was too late but a little surprised how dead things were. Supposed to be some sort of historic place but was generally unimpressive.

1. Bloody Marys... so good2. The bread3. The butter (cabot's salted) mmm mmm mmmmm4. The picklesThose are 4 things I think I could live my life on happily and if we were ever under attack I would flee to this bar.. it's been there since 1817, I think it could survive a martian or nuclear attack.
i swear to gawd there was a vampire sitting two tables over.He interacted with nobody, sat alone, and had fangs.turns out that he was part of the little jazz trio that started right about midnight.
Solid music on Sunday nights as well as good dark beer and great company.
This place is just cool. Old fashioned. Simple. Plus you can color on the tables :]

This place is a waste of prime real estate. Being situated next the hudson, it probably hasn't been renovated since its inception which is god knows when. The place smells like it has an asbestos problem. The wood is rotting. The beer taps are not clean so beer tastes like crap. The food is meh at best, but the service is horrible with an attitude to boot. Do yourself a favor and find any number of bars nearby to go to before checking this shithole out
Great atmosphere and bar food, live music twice a week, and they even have their own Ear Ale brewed by Brooklyn Brewery. The Ear never gets old.

Not at all what you think it's going to be from the outside.  Fun historical bar with a lot of character.  Great prices, great selection.  We didn't eat, but the food next to us smelled good.  It would totally be my local bar...if I lived there.

I really wish I could give this place 4.5 stars, I just have a tough time rounding up to 5. This place does have a special charm that is hard to find now at modern places. The burger was perfectly cooked, big and tasty. The drinks are very reasonably priced for NYC and the Irish guy behind the bar has to be one of my favorite bartenders ever. If I ever find myself over there again I would love to make another visit.

Last of the decent places to eat and drink in this area.When the neighborhood opens up a nightclub down the block that is "Eco-friendly" you can best bet a place like this is on the endangered species list.Ear Inn has great atmosphere that cant be replicated or imitated.The character of this place can only be earned by the test of time. Dining area reminds me of a set from the movie Popeye, and the food is surprisingly good. Please try to go while its still around.
One of my favorite bars; arguably the best Guinness on tap in the City. An old-fashioned vibe and great staff. You can sense the history at the Ear.
Wholesome with food, ale and OK music

The ear inn is arguably one of the best restaurants in lower Manhattan. everything is spot on. It's very cozy and warm. The burgers are soOooOoO goood!. The home fries that come with the burger are SOOOOOOOO gooood. I hope this place stays in business for millions of years. I hope it never changes. When the apocalypse comes I want to be here. When I'm enjoying being with my friends I don't want to waste the time taking guesses on other joints. This is the place. Forever and ever my love will not be broken.

Named an Inn but really only a Bar. They claim to be one of the oldest bars in NYC but they really aren't at all. If you read their history (which is on the back of their menu) you'll see that they might be one of the oldest buildings in New York with a rich history but the bar actually hasn't been there all that long. If you want to go to the oldest bar in the city you'll have to go to McSorley's. Ear Inn is a smelly dirty dive bar with very few redeeming qualities. I haven't had any of their food but great food would have to be the only real reason to earn anything beyond 3 stars.
Biker bar at its best on Tues nights 6-9 come have a drink the food looks good also BIKES BIKES BIKES!

This is a cool place to go. I only had drinks there late at night but I loved the atmosphere. Not a fancy place and their customers are very laid back.I didn't eat there but I heard that food there is pretty decent; maybe I will give a try next time.Man...this place is sooooooooooooooo  old. The building was built in 1817. It is also know as "The green door". Some people say the place is haunted.Boo!!!Restrooms are ridiculously small.It's nice that they are not afraid of reviews. If you go tho their website they have a link of lots of websites that review their place, like Yelp (which make me like them better!)What else do you need?? Go there!Anyway...It's a landmark!!!
Great location by the water.  Cool old tavern vibe, with extremely reasonably priced food.  When its nice out everyone is out front.

NYC's second oldest bar.This place is crawling with character and historic flavor. Great place to grab a drink and connect with friends. The food is good, nothing to write home about but it's hearty nature is reminiscent of home cooking and compliments the bar's vibe. The decor and ambiance are refreshing and authentic. There are many places built in the last decade that try to emulate the charm and charisma of this old-timey watering hole, but the Ear Inn is the real deal and not trying to be something it's notBike nights on Tuesdays for the motorcycle and gear heads. Seems to be mostly European bikes, moto guzzis, triumphs, ducatis, bmws, and the likes, but it's welcome to all.

I've been coming to this bar/restaurant since 1992.  Does that make me an old fart?  And unlike it's Meatpacking District contemporary, (at least in my mind) Florent...The Ear is still here!!!  The Black and Tans are just as good as they ever were and the food is at a surprisingly high standard given that this is an old and I mean OLD bar and the kitchen probably dates back to prohibition era or before.  All this and you get the world's cutest, tiniest sink in the Ladies room.

A constant crowd of smokers outside suggests the Ear is packed on a Friday at 6:30, but quite the contrary. Inside, it's crowded, but there are plenty of tables available. The burger is delicious, served with buttery oven-roasted potatoes and a slight salad. Top it with cheese, order a beer, and push through the crowd outside to take a mid-evening cigarette in. Classic bar. Classic food. Classic booze. Hear me?
Cute and quaint little place.  I only had a glass of wine but I will be sure to visit again when I'm in the neighborhood.  A great date spot.  Bike rack right in front!

This place is awesome! Best burgers that I have try in NYC so far! It is quiet, no tourists messing around, genuine American style, supernice waiters... I love it, one of my favorite spots in the city!
Laid-back atmosphere, quick and friendly service, but average pub food.

Mediocre, bland food.  Nice old building, but it's not like New York is wanting for those."I shouldn't trust a single local opinion over checking Yelp," I thought as we ate here with a friend.  But it looks like Yelp would have failed us, too.
This place has excellent food. Everything I have had-- mainly burgers, soup, salad, BLTs-- is first rate. And it's also a historic bar, quite worth a visit even if all you want is a beer.

Tis the season for reflecting upon what we are thankful for.  In the holiday spirit - thank you Ear Inn.  Thank you for a not awful Shiraz when I simply can't drink any more beer.  Thank you for the crayons and butcher paper to let the world finally see my drunken stick-figure-drawing genius.  Thank you for not being critical when I top my turkey burger with bacon, cheddar and avocado.  Thank you for always keeping the heat on.  Thank you for sparing me from the obnoxious overheard in NY conversations with your no cell phone policy.  Thank you for all the nights I was having such a lovely time that I didn't even get upset when Peter Dinklage gave me death stares for an apparent reason.Thank you & Happy Holidays.

Been here a few times for after-work drinks and birthdays (it's close to the office). Today, though, I saw a roach on the table next to ours, told one of our servers, and she did nothing. Luckily, we were almost done so we asked for the check, but then it crawled over to us and almost went in my colleague's bag. The other server with the leopard spots tat on her neck at least apologized and said they exterminate every tuesday, but i probably wont be back here anytime soon.

The 2ND oldest bar in the city and, correct me if I'm wrong, it has also been designated as a landmark! But this is not the only attraction...The laid back atmosphere, the great service, the secluded location, and the feel like you've traveled to a far away area, where every patron seems like distant family members, make this one of the must places to frequent in the city.You walk towards it, and you look up at a sign which, to the naked eye, should say "bar inn" and half the lights of the letter B burned out. But that is not the case my friends, as it is done on purpose (I think with some sort of paint). Thus the name Ear Inn. When you walk in you know right away that this place has been standing forever. It's like walking into an antique shop. However, the beer and the food are anything but antique.The burgers are great, and they make it anyway you like it. They also have a chalkboard with everyday specials. When they have it, their salmon burger and calamari are also great choices.

I love this place, period.  I used to work nearby and went for lunch there 2-3 times a week & to drink after work 2-3 times a week.  The food is great (but come on, a few more pieces of potato in an Irish place would be nice) and the beer is righteous...  the crowd is laid back and don't even think of pulling out you iphone ... you will be shown the door.
They are super nice to bikers, especially on Tues when we congregate on the sidewalk for sunset.  Great burgers, chill staff.

The food ain't fancy, but it's darn good. How two guys in a kitchen the size of a closet can dish up such tasty bites is beyond me, but they do it. Great burgers but no fries. Most dishes including the burgers are served with a little salad and roasted red potatoes. Specials change everyday in a sort of regular rotation. Don't miss Shepard's Pie Thursday. The chicken pot pie is also a winner - flaky crust, big chunks of white meat chicken. The place itself is a history lesson in old NY. Believe it or not it was at one time right on the waterfront - now it's a good two blocks off it 'cause of all the landfill. Prices are good and the waitresses work as a team so you're never waiting long for anything including another ice -cold pint.Wheelchair access: Getting in is easy. It's cramped, but the folks there are always nice and they'll get you seated no problem. The bathroom... hmmm... there's a Starbucks a few blocks up on Varick and Spring.

This place is chock full of architects during happy hour... so ladies and gentlemen.. if you've got a thing for archies, heres the place to pick them up! 

I've never had food here, but I hear its pretty good. 

What I like most about this place is that whenever I go during happy hour, theres always a ton of people there. I love sitting outside in the summer, and this is one of those places where you can drink your beer out on the sidewalk and not get arrested!

i would go so far to say that this is my new favorite place to eat and booze in NYC.as you walk up to the random location in soho, you see very cool people hanging outside, just drinking beers and chilling. open container!!!the interior is eclectic, full of creaky floorboards, old signs, ephemera, collectibles, antiques...overstimulating and crowded. noisy. packed in. but amazing.for 3 people to eat dinner on a thursday night, it was a 45 min wait. worth it, though! dinner is like $10, which is amazing for NYC. it was really good with huge portions (i got the veggie burger which comes with a salad and yummy potatoes, friend got burger and other friend got the grilled salmon.) dinner for 3 was $45!!!i love the ambiance. i think very cool people go here and appreciate the historic value. i had been trying to get over here for a while and so happy i finally did! can't wait to hang here during the summer months.

Perfect spot for lunch in SoHo or TriBeCa.  Especially if you're on Broadway with out of town friends or family (or hey, even locals) and want to escape the madness and find a bite to eat that's not some weird fashionista tourist thing (overplayed paninis, sad little salads, and the like).  Stepping in here feels like you've crossed over into another place (lonely one-horse town in the middle of nowhere, or hey, at least some godforsaken part of Queens), maybe even another time.  Great food, plenty of good beers, though I always just order a Guinness.

I meet up here every Tuesday night for 'Bike Night'. Just hanging with fellow motorcycle enthusiasts of all types. Ducati's, Triumph's, Suzuki's, MV's, Harley's. It's all family here, and to be quite honest, that's pretty goddamn special. Have a beer and talk bikes [beers allowed outside, just don't step foot in the street or the cutie 'bouncer' will be all over you (maybe not such a bad thing)].

Martin, the owner, responded with class, and promised to speak to Mickey. I'm impressed how quickly he replied. Based on this I do change my rating... because the bar really is one of the best in the city... thanks Martin!!

This is a great after work spot. Low key, good drinks, a "mind your own business" type of attitude which is a PLUS. Every now and then, they have a live band playing in the corner which can be entertaining when inebriated enough.Only bad part about it is the very, VERY cramped spaces. They can't possibly expect drunken people to wiggle through between those tables unscathed do they?

I'm told this is the 2nd oldest bar in the city, we walked past the 1st oldest on our way to Burp Castle.It had a great vibe, Hooegaarden on tap (my new favorite beer), and the smallest bathroom ever, so cute!Wish we had stayed longer since the rest of our night was a bust, but we stuck to our one drink maximum.

After reading numerous reviews on this place I decided to check it out, as it is within walking distance of my apartment. I came here on a Wednesday night and wow-it was crowded. Just as people described with cool memoribiila on the walls and a very "old" feeling inside. The food was good and cheap-very reasonable considering the area. I was here early-around 8 so I am not sure what it turns into later at night but this place seemed much more restaurant than bar to me. Almost the entire place is taken up by tables which is fine if you want to sit with friends but it is not really the typical bar scene I was expecting. All in all, I will definitely go back here with a small group of friends for the good food, nice and attentive wait staff and crayons on the tables.

Mighty impressive!  Came here for lunch, so this is a food review.  It's a small cozy place hidden amongst the towering buildings in the West Village.  I had a burger and I must say it was very good.  It was cooked a little more than I asked for, but it was still juicy.  The homefries instead of normal fries is an interesting touch - but not a bad one at that.A relaxed atmosphere for lunch in the city is something not to be overlooked.

I ate here with a couple of friends a couple of weeks ago after attending an event in the area. It was a Wednesday night and the place was packed. After waiting for a table for about an hour (we waited because it was freezing and we were hungry so we just stayed...), having a drink at the bar in the meantime, we were finally seated. Once we sat and looked at the menu I could see one of the reasons the place was so packed! The food is so cheap - and really good! The atmosphere is really cozy. (I think its one of the older bars in the city). I had the Cobb salad, it was great. The mussels looked and smelled awesome. Definitely getting them next time, looking forward to going back...
Excellent mussels appetizer and the burger was baller!  Can't beat the history and decor.  Mixed, laid-back clientele crowd the place for a reason.

say it isn't so................I was leaving sway the other night and could have sworn there is a new building built on top of the ear......just soo wierd to have this institution built in 1817 with a brand new condo residence on top of it?!?You can feel the history at this bar.  Belly up for a beer - (don't even think about ordering a swanky cocktail here).  Brunch is surprisingly good - get the irish breakfast.

Going to the Ear Inn sort of gives you the same feeling as slipping into a pair of your grandfather's leather oxfords - old, warn-in, smelly, and familiar....all in a good way. Props for steadfastness and fortitude. Believe it or not I had a very romantic brunch there years ago, and it's a fun place to go for drinks too.

One of the oldest bars in New York (est. 1817), the Ear Inn is a nice place to get a beer, a table and some friends together and enjoy the evening.  I was there on a Friday night.  The service is really good, for one thing.  After ordering at the bar, we had a waitress coming by every five minutes making sure we were ok.  There's a standard selection of good beers on tap (Stella & Brooklyn Lager are the only two I can remember off hand).  Flat screen TV for Yankee games.  At some point well past midnight, it got really crowded and noisy, but in the Eleven o'clock hour it was moderately full.  For a (very) old school New York experience, visit the Ear Inn.

Cozy.  That is the first word that comes to mind.  I know it is old, and it looks old, but doesn't _feel_ old, at least not like McSoreleys does.  That isn't a bad thing though.Its small, but has a bar and a number of tables - which was nice for me the night I dropped by.  I just needed a little something to eat before hitting Don Hill's for Amateur Female Jello Wrestling, and wasn't looking for hanging out at the bar.The tables have your standard big pieces of butcher paper on them (the roll is back by the john) and a couple condiments.  I just ordered a cup of the Vegetable Barley soup - my waitress was non-plussed.  I'm sure I saw the tip-based dollar signs vanish from her eyes when I said it.  Oh well.I got a nice big chunk of bread with some butter (cold and hard unfortunately) and a goodly sized "cup" of soup.  It was pretty damn tasty.  I wasn't expecting to be as impressed as I was.  Even had bread left over once I was done with the soup.When I bailed I made sure to leave as sizable a tip as I could.  I know how it goes w/ the service industry...So, if you are in this cold part of town, duck into the Ear Inn for something to warm you up.  You won't be disappointed.

If Ear Inn was any better, I might be dead today.I went to this fine historic establishment last night for one of my many "last nights" out in NY with coworkers and I drank my face off.  7 (imperial) pints of Guinness and some fried dumplings for dinner, does not a good morning make. Although the dumplings were very tasty and probably saved me from uncertain death...I had a wonderful time last night.  The bartenders were all very nice.  Buybacks are frequent.  The atmosphere is lively, but not crazy. And although it's as old as they come, it didn't feel run down and decrepit!  I'd definitely go back and take friends, if I was staying in NY longer that is.One of the many reasons I'll miss this amazing city.

I'm seduced by nostalgia.Any place with a history as long as Ear Inn's is gonna be an instant favorite of mine.I could bypass the hoards of bankers who hang out here after work, but who am I to judge.Friendly staff, cheap drinks, some outdoor seating - a trusted spot in that neighborhood.

I went here last night for a going away get-together for a friend who was moving back to Europe. I probably would have never ventured to this place had it not been for her (it's quite far from my humble abode in Brooklyn), but I'm so happy I did! The Ear Inn is a little piece of history. When you walk into the place you can feel it. But it doesn't feel dirty or dated. And it's completely unpretentious!Grab a table with some friends, get a beer (you'd be crazy to drink mixed drinks here), and relax. It is such a perfect winter spot to come in and escape the cold!

A couple really nice things about this place. Its on a great block, its really not a tucked away gem because there are about 4 other bar/restaurants on the same block, a hipster club, and another bar around the corner. Its always full of a lively, mostly older crowd that's very warm and inviting. You remember the small scene where Helen Hunt and her mother in As Good As It Gets are walking to the bar after they have a little tif and emotional scene and they just need to go out? that bar that they walk into and they give hugs to their friends and the music twinkles in a Hallmark Hall of Fame TV movie of the week way? That's this bar right here. Simple.

The Ear Inn is my favorite bar and restaurant in the city. Great food and welcoming atmosphere. The cornerstone of this historic establishment, Mickey, always has a kind word to say to, and about, everyone who is fortunate enough to met him. Credit cards are no issue and he loves to make complex, delicious drinks, no matter how busy the bar is. His margaritas and martinis are incredible! Further, you can sit outside and drink, and Mickey doesn't even make you leave a card! If I ever have a son, I will certainly ask Mickey to be his godfather.

My husband & I must have ridden our bikes by this places a million times... so, we finally decide to make a stop for a beer.  The young server was ever so sweet & kind & gave me a menu list of the beers they had & I asked here if we can sit outside w/our beers... she said yes.  I showed the menu to my husband who was sitting outside.  Went back inside to order & before I can even say one word, the EXTREMELY rude & condescending bartender told me that we can not eat outside and that I would need to order from him and only him and again felt that he needed to repeat himself 'we can not eat outside'.  Not a 'hi, how are you?' or 'hi, what can I can for you to drink?'  Just pure rudeness.  I just walked right out and left this place,, there are plenty of bars who I rather give my money to and establishments that hire more 'customer friendly employees'.

The Ear is my favorite bar in NYC. I love it so much that I forgive it for being in Manhattan. I visited the Ear for the first time at age 16 on a weekday afternoon in 1993 and Debbie Harry was at the next table. I have loved this place ever since.The food is excellent. Don't even bother looking at the printed menu. Everything you want to order (oh... right, unless you want a burger... which I suppose you might) is on the chalkboard specials list. This is a rare place in the city where you can get a full meal - entree with two sides (vegetable of the day and usually a rice pilaf of some sort) for under $10. The chicken marsala, when they have it, is great and, like, $8 or $9. There is nothing exceptional about it at all, but I even love the bread and butter that you get while you wait for your food. Because I am cheap and it is very affordable and drinkable, I always have the house wine when I go. Also, the PIES are wonderful. So, save room for dessert.

I love this place!  I've been coming here for over 16 years and it's still my number one favorite place to meet old friends for a casual and comfortable night out.  The food is always dependable and affordable--always FRESH, and the atmosphere is unpretentious, welcoming and cozy--it's one of the few places a woman can sit alone at the bar just having a drink or a burger and feel totally at home.  There's just something indescribable about the vibe at THe Ear--all I know is whenever I'm there, I laugh A LOT, drink good wine feeling like I've just had one of those nights out in the city that make me glad I live here and that there are neighborhood places like this that still exist even in SOHO where expensive uptight restaurants can sometimes wear me down...

I love the ear.  The drinks and food are a mite over priced for the quality, but it's by no means expensive.  It's really the building itself that is the draw here.The place reeks of history.  It's been in operation since the early 1800's and continues to draw a laid back crowd to it's relatively out of the way locale.  One of my favorite talking points of the Ear is the mooring post in front that indicates the former Hudson River line.  Manhattan has grown literally 1/2 a mile wider since The Ear was founded.  It's not too often you can get a pint of Guinness and a history lesson at the same spot.

This place is relaxing.  Yes, it's loud and crowded, but it's also without pretention and everyone there is so damn friendly so you can really get comfortable.Order the clam chowder.  It goes so well with a cold beer.  Creamy heaven.

Nice bar! Came here for beer. Nice customer service, good crowd, music. Will come back for those bar hopping nights. Oh, and owner gave my party and I a free round of beer and shots. I mean, too awesome!
Live (really good) jazz and good burgers and an actual bottle of wine in the oldest bar in NY. How come I didn't know about this gem.

Perhaps for some people the atmosphere makes up for the nearly inedible food.  The atmosphere is a that of a cozy bar, with paper on the tables and crayons that invite you to doodle while you wait.  That was fine.  It was the chicken that was a problem, both on my Cobb salad and on my boyfriend's pasta dish, and I think it had more salt that the recommended daily allowance.  Perhaps we ordered wrong--maybe a burger would have been fine.  But I won't be heading back to find out.  That chicken was unforgivable.

The Ear Inn was the first bar (I stumbled into when lost late one night) when I first arrived in New York City a decade ago. Love this place. Don't think this pathetic, but I practically took jobs and moved into an apartment in TriBeCa just so I could be near this place. (Sort of.) The food is great, but the atmosphere is greater. Food first... I quite often get the spicy shrimp (app) and a side of mashed taters (just like an Irish Ma's). But the burgers are amazing and the roasted taters (that they offer with nearly everything) are perfect. They're menu always has a chicken, a fish, a meat and a pasta dish - all vary from day to day. You can never go wrong with their chicken dishes. Always good. If you go there on a pork chop night - get it! If you prefer to intake the calories via the booze, but need a lil something for sustenance, they have nice salads to choose from. I love their cesar salad, but have a really appreciation for their grilled shrimp on mescalin. The atmosphere... Ok, well there are plenty of bars out there who can throw together their atmosphere to look like a boat house or a hunting lodge or a pub of old Ireland. The Ear is special, tho. The place is the past, quite liter tally. The decor (if you even want to use that fancy a word to describe it) hasn't changed much since it's time as a boatman's bar. Did I mention that they pour the best beer in town? And the bartenders are really great people. Wait staff are also total sweetness.I think one of the best things about the place (which unfortunately the suits have picked up on over the years) is the outdoor seating. A nice little grandfather clause allows Ear patrons to have their frothy ales and hardy stouts outside. There's really nothing like a nice pint with a cool summer breeze while watching the sunset down the block.So, yeah... Ear Inn. I love you.

I didn't eat here, but sat at the bar drinking beer while my cousins eat. The 1st cousin had the beef stew which he raved about and the other cousin had the special bison/buffalo burger which he didn't like cause he's a dumb-ass & didn't realize that buffalo doesn't taste like beef .... Wowever, the hoegaardens (beer) were very quaff-able the service was decent, the food smelled and looked great and seemed inexpensive for the quality/quanity. I must head back here next time I'm in this part of town to get something to eat.

Whether it's the proper pint up at the bar served up by Gary or a Tuesday special of a Chicken Pot Pie, or maybe a Black & Tan brought to you at your table by the proprietor, Martin, this place has the market cornered...A true zone of antiquity in a rapidly desensitized Soho neighborhood, this Bar is flanked by some giant sterile glass apartment buildings that rival that of the dreaded Meyer Towers...Forever a West Soho staple right up to the shoreline, this is a timeless place where the pints are always full and the plates are too.  Reasonably priced, trusty food is the name of the game here, nothing too fancy.  On Sunday's let the 'Earregulars' give you an earfull of Jazz while you grab a mouthful of their garlic shrimp or the pork chop.

I love this place. It seems to be a hangout for tech startup employees in the area. Delicious burgers, a wide selection of beer, and an ancient pedigree - the place claims to have been founded in 1817. The interior is, ah, a little divey, but I still love it. Great place for groups and spontaneous celebratory beers.

Bordering the Hudson River on the fabulous street of Spring, the Ear Inn is where you will find a happy and humming crowd gathered outside drinking beer and enjoying life.  On Sundays the bar is converted from a jolly ol' Irish vibe to a bikers world.  Come for fun and a pint of beer.

Super cute bar in SoHo.  The interior feels like that of an old ship: rickety, old, cozy, and possibly hiding a chest full of gold pieces in a corner.  Outdoor seating is limited.  Hence, people carry out folding chairs and set them up on the sidewalk to sit on while they guzzle some booze and read a book.  The place has a wonderful, spontaneous, antique-y feel to it.  Not much like it in the area, so make sure you stop by.
Great food at a good price!  Nice older place.
like my favorite place ever. great food, never a long wait, cool if not a bit disenchanted older crowd of new yorkers. their dumplings and shrimp scampi are great.

everyone has an opinion. it's true! i mean, f*ck, i use yelp. of course i want you all to know what i think.but, as far as i am concerned, i think the ear inn's burger is not good. i like burgers; i eat them whenever they are available, especially if everyone raves. raves including but not limited to; best burger in new york, best burger ever, best burger on the west side, etc.so, i came all the way from brooklyn to go to lunch here. it's WAY over on the west side, and contrary to what the map says, the ear inn is not technically INSIDE the holland tunnel.i order the legendary burger and while i wait, i take in the old OLD bar, dusty ephemera and quite a few business lunch drinkers. i like the bar part. i love old things. dusty old man bar spaces.burger came. man alive. dry. boring. NOT medium-rare (i.e. no bloody juice). i didn't finish it. that's saying something.so, i guess people like this place, but i am not one of those people.

I really do love this place - chill and low-key, and not at all pretentious. The mussels look (& smell) wonderful, although I'm being naughty by reviewing even though I haven't probably eaten there in a decade. I recall their burger was excellent, though.I did find it annoying that their bathroom leaves a lot to be desired. I'll leave it at that.

I like Ear Inn. It is a hike from where I live, but I love the outdoor area and the easy going nature of the place. I have only been for after dinner cocktails, but would love to come back for dinner. Prices are pretty good too ;)

I came here on a Sunday night with some friends to have a beer or two and relax, and that's just what we did. The bartender was cool and so was the vibe. We all had a great time and look forward to going back.

Fun place with an interesting history. Down side is the random location. Plus side is that there was no problem grabbing a seat to eat dinner at 8 on a Saturday night. What's going to bring me back is the crowd, the crayons and the fact that my friends and I got to reminisce all evening to a great selection of 90s rock (think Oasis and Blur).

A very good place to wet your whistle late at night.  It's in the far west area of SoHo, so make sure you know how to get there because the surroundings can be vacant.  They give you alot for your money.  You can really get drunk quick in a nice atmosphere.  I think the bartender was drunk when I came because I asked for a double shot and he gave me the equivalent of like 5 shots.  Not alot of females when I went there, but a genuine Irish bar filled with people who love to drink.
Yup.  A really good old bar.  Be ready to hoist a few.

I have finally found the mecca of my slumming around, dive bar looking fun!  This is what you think of when you think of going to a dive bar.Now I know you are afraid that it might be a little bridge and tunnel, but we can't keep everything to ourselves.  Just get ready to drink some cold draft beers, nice cocktails and to be blasted with a crowded bar full of people!  But it is fun!  I am telling you this.

Great bar for pints, food, meeting friends.The ear inn was a longshoreman's bar, and has been slowly maturing at its location for over 100 years.  The bar is ancient and solid and the atmosphere is friendly and den like -- almost smoky like an old bar should be (just seems that way, there's no smoking there nowadays).For a bar, they really care about some of the food: the fish of the day is often a real treat.  Don't feel compelled to order food if you sit at a table: the waitresses are happy to serve you beer to your heart's content.Not for your chi-chi friends, but everyone else will appreciate.

You can always count on Ear Inn for decent food and a good atmosphere. If you try anything, the chili is a must. For the value you receive, it cannot be beat! The food is good, not great, but worth every penny! I will definitely return to this place. The live music helps the overall atmosphere. The servers are nice and the service is good.

One of the Ear Inn's most important assets is the barstaff, who, as soon as you sit down, insist that you have a drink.  This works well because with a small draft selection and the 5 bottle choices displayed, you should be able to make your decision in the amount of time necessary to order at McDonalds.  Previous reviewers mention wine so I'll assume that's also an option, but the Ear Inn isn't really a wine-drinking kind of place. While I know that food's on the menu and many reviewers have treated primarily as such, I still regard the Ear Inn as a drinking establishment cum restaurant, much along the lines of Melon's. It's similarly timeworn (to be fair, Much more so: it's been here since the 1817) and from what I can tell, attracts a similarly regular crowd. And it's in a gorgeous federal-style house.  As the Hudson is in plain sight outside the doors, there's a nautical theme. I gather that this was a sailor bar for most of its history and really does a remarkable job of maintaining this feel. The huge functional cleat outside the door bespeaks authenticity that's lacking at, say, the Rusty Knot or the Anchor. Notably, there's also a massive ear affixed to the wall.  On a somewhat tangential note, its seafaring proclivities didn't deter the crowd of bikers who, on a recent Tuesday, made the Ear Inn the only "biker bar" I've visited in Manhattan, and the only biker/sailor bar I've seen anywhere. As a bar, it's a better choice than the other options in far-west Soho and worth a visit if you're near.

Antiquated but hardly quaint, great sunset views in the summertime, tasty burgers, chili, and the like (although I peeked in the kitchen to see who was serving up such heart-warming fare, and they're chinese!!!  i swear to god!!)...its my "cheers" bar only without the annoying characters.  unless i'm actually one of the annoying characters.  doh!  :(

my friend took me to this place we had a few beers and Shimp Scampi - i believe that's what it is called.  It was really good: spicy and garlic shrimp with toasted bread.  went well with the beers.  thanks buddy!

What a lovely little destination on the far west side of Spring Street. Stepping into Ear Inn is like stepping back in time. The place is full of eye candy with its cool signs, charming antique bottle, and historical mementos.  Caught a Saturday afternoon poetry series, which added to the ambiance of this old space. A hidden gem in NYC, and what a gem it is!

A very charming find - we had a drink and drew on the paper tablecloths with the provided crayons. I hear the food is good too, definitely must come back at an earlier hour for dinner then sit around and drink!

just a nice, honest place serving decent food and good beer. the ambience is warm and inviting, and it wasn't too loud. they did, however, play a U2 album from start to finish, which although not an unforgivable sin, is as close as you can get. 5 stars if the music were better.
Friendly neighborhood bar frequented by local hip office crowds.  Old but charming atmosphere.  Decent food serviced with a smile  -- the menu is limited though.Recommendation: steak.

I wouldn't call the Ear Inn a dive bar but for some reason it feels like one. I find that to be a good thing. The clientele here kick ass (maybe litter ally most of them are bikers in the summer) and I am really impressed with the burgers. The place had a gritty feel but is actually quite clean and great place to have a rocking one-on-one with an old pal.

This is a great little place to get a drink or a good pub meal. One of the oldest bars in New York, it really gives the feel of a dusty Irish pub. You can sit outside in the summer which is cool, but be aware that motorcyclists frequent this place, at least on Thursdays. It's cool if you like bikes since they park them right out front, but it gets a bit crowded. The food is good, and perhaps a bit underrated, too. Great burgers and sandwiches, but don't hesitate to order something slightly less run-of-the-mill. Anything that seems distinctly Irish or English--like Shepherd's Pie--is bound to be good. Great beers on tap like Sierra and Boddington's and the taps are kept pretty clean. It's reasonably priced, but not necessarily cheap. Definitely worth the stop if you're in the area.

Established in 1817, with wall detritus to proove it (one of the posters on the wall is an urgent WWII plea for soldiers). The place is always packed around sunset because they have a nice view and plenty of benches outside to watch from. When the weather is fine New Yorkers make the most of it. They also have live music quite frequently. Everyone there feels like a regular.
Definitely a good place to grab a pint.  Live music, mellow vibe, and an outdoor area.

I used to live down the street, and probably went here to eat and have drinks 3 out of the 7 days in a week.  The food is good, and very reliable.   The waitstaff is friendly, but the bartenders are not.

A very pleasant spot.  I had a very good burger for $8.  Johnnie Cash at midnight, followed by some great live jazz (a nice surprise on a Tuesday night).  An older crowd, including a dozen or two on motorcycles.  A cute waitress with an enchanting Irish accent.
Loved sitting outside...feels like you're having a beer at a great barbecue, except you're on a sidewalk.

Have never been treated in such a disrespectful way!!! I met here with 2 friends just before 6pm on a Sunday evening to get a couple of drinks and some food before a movie premiere. We talked to the bar tender who told us that we could sit anywhere so we picked a table in the front. After 15 minutes without service (not even water - it was 95 degrees outside) we tried to get the attention of one of the waitresses who were busy chatting to a customer at the bar. More and more people started walking in and sat down in the back. The 2 waitresses started taking orders and tried the best to ignore us. A lady sat down next to us and got the menu right away. My friend asked her if we could order something (at that point we've been waiting for more than 25 minutes). Without saying anything she stared pulling the paper cloth from the table. I asked her if something was wrong and she almost shouted back saying that the table wasn't set up for dinner and that we had to move which we subsequently did. After another 5 minutes she gave us the menu. We said that we were ready to order which she ignored and ran away again! I was already steaming but I didn't want to disappoint my friend who had recommended the restaurant. So I suggested that we could order a drink at the bar and sit outside. The bar tender poured us drinks and I gave him my credit card. He asked me if I had cash. When I denied he said that there was a 2 Dollar charge for credits cards which I've never heard about. I should have walked out but paid and didn't leave a tip. Shame. Will never ever go back and would never recommend this place to anyone.

This is a really cozy, tucked away spot that I think is really old. If you're looking for somewhere to watch sports on a small TV out of the corner of your eye while whispering sweet nothings to your date who is eating something hearty and delicious from the modestly priced menu, this is your place. They had Christmas caroling for the holidays, and even passed out the words to all the songs the band was singing. I bet it's great in the summer too.

Been here once.  Loved the history of this place.  But I felt kind of weird here- like I just walked into something personal.  Everyone knows each other and there are def. lots of regulars (so it seemed), so it takes awhile to get used to if you plan to become a regular yourself.

we come here after work when we've had a long day and want to get hammered.  why?  because they have the most ridiculously strong jack and cokes EVER.  AND they have CRAYONS so you can draw on the table.  and that helps also when you are trying to divvy up the bill.  doing long division with crayons while drunk trying to figure out how you are going to pay the bill on the crap salary you are getting paid at your crap job that drove you to drink in the first place will no doubt make you crumble into a drunken pile of mush when you start reminiscing on your childhood.  burnt sienna.  best color ever.also, good comfort food and nice service and titanic memorabilia and it's loud and you can be belligerent and no one will judge you.  at least no one will judge you that you will see.  because you will have your drunk blinders on.  thank you jack and coke and the quick servers that keep them coming.
Perfect for a lazy day of drinking, I have started many a drunken night here! Very cool local feel too!

This place is great! Went here in the summertime and had a beer while sitting out front on the sidewalk, then moved inside and got some appetizers once our friends arrived. The food was all tasty and the beer selection was decent. It was very crowded, but not in a bad way. It's quite cozy, it feels like everyone knows one another. The paper covered tables + crayons raise it to a five star....come on, who doesn't like coloring and drinking??

Very cool, laid back bar in the west village. It's an excellent place to do some cheap outdoor drinking before heading to any of he clubs in the area. I always hit up Ear Inn before going to Don Hills.

Light jazz played in the background as I ducked through the front door of this cramped little west-soho bar.  The room was dimly lit and comfortable.  It's said to be one of the oldest bars left on the island and I believe it.  Solid wood bar and antique maritime acoutrements lining the walls create an ambience of relaxed casual fun.  The waitresses were friendly and attentive and a couple good baseball games were playing.  The beer was cold and served quickly.  The food was not amazing but  certainly not bad.  As the night pressed on, my friend arrived and cold beers continued to as well.  A couple recently married were dancing next to the bar still in black tie and white dress(apparently they had met here years ago).  If I lived down the street, I might come here every night.  As I walked toward the door, a single trumpet lamented the end of the night and so did I.

I love this place. I used to come here more than once with an ex-girlfriend, and the memories linger. I also know it was one of the only bars in the area before the big building boom, and when SOHO was still for artists. I used to get a great steak dish, and the ex had a burger. It's like you've stepped into a movie set of a 'New York' place. Yeah, it's a dive-hole, but that's part of the charm. I feel like there's a good enough mix of the locals, tourists, outsiders etc. to give it up a thumbs-up. Good if you're driving home from upstate, on the West Side, and want to get dinner before making it back to Brooklyn.
unquie atmosphere a good pub for a few pints and u could meet anytype there! its really cool like the irish stew fridays too

Great food, and great prices! It was a little crammed and busy, and the waitress seemed to have a little bit of a "hurry up and order already" attitude, but other than that, I can't complain. This would make for a great place to meet up for drinks and dinner during the week... it looks like it could get super busy on the weekends. Very close to the Hudson, so probably nice for a date/stroll after dinner kind of place.
